<a name='F-acknowledge'></a>
### acknowledge `constants`

##### Summary

Represents the acknowledge pin.

##### Remarks

This pin cannot be set in user mode.

<a name='F-all'></a>
### all `constants`

##### Summary

Requests sampling of all sensors.

##### Remarks

This should only be used for filtering when creating the sensor
instances. In end-user code, it is usually an indication that
something is going wrong if this value is used.

<a name='F-alternating_current'></a>
### alternating_current `constants`

##### Summary

Alternating current coupling, which will enable a high-pass filter
to remove the DC offset voltage from the trigger signal.

<a name='F-alternating_current_limit'></a>
### alternating_current_limit `constants`

##### Summary

Removes the DC offset voltage from the input signal.

<a name='F-amd'></a>
### amd `constants`

##### Summary

Identifies an AMD CPU.

<a name='F-ampere'></a>
### ampere `constants`

##### Summary

The channel measures current.

<a name='F-asic'></a>
### asic `constants`

##### Summary

`ADL_PMLOG_ASIC_POWER` or `ADL_PMLOG_SSPAIRED_ASICPOWER`.

<a name='F-automatic'></a>
### automatic `constants`

##### Summary

The instrument triggers repeatedly after a time interval if the
configured tigger conditions are not fulfiled. If a real trigger
occurs, it takses precedence.

<a name='F-automatically'></a>
### automatically `constants`

##### Summary

Determine the measurement range automatically.

##### Remarks

The instrument will adjust the measurement range by itself as
necessary. However, if that happens, any integration of values will
fail, wherefore it is reasonable to set an explicit or the maximum
possible range if integration is desired.

<a name='F-average_of_1'></a>
### average_of_1 `constants`

##### Summary

Return the latest sample.

<a name='F-average_of_1024'></a>
### average_of_1024 `constants`

##### Summary

Sliding average over 1024 samples.

<a name='F-average_of_128'></a>
### average_of_128 `constants`

##### Summary

Sliding average over 128 samples.

<a name='F-average_of_16'></a>
### average_of_16 `constants`

##### Summary

Sliding average over 16 samples.

<a name='F-average_of_256'></a>
### average_of_256 `constants`

##### Summary

Sliding average over 256 samples.

<a name='F-average_of_4'></a>
### average_of_4 `constants`

##### Summary

Sliding average over four samples.

<a name='F-average_of_512'></a>
### average_of_512 `constants`

##### Summary

Sliding average over 512 samples.

<a name='F-average_of_64'></a>
### average_of_64 `constants`

##### Summary

Sliding average over 64 samples.

<a name='F-begin'></a>
### begin `constants`

##### Summary

Beginning of file.

<a name='F-bhyve'></a>
### bhyve `constants`

##### Summary

Identifies the bhyve hypervisor.

<a name='F-board'></a>
### board `constants`

##### Summary

Total board power (`ADL_PMLOG_BOARD_POWER`).

<a name='F-both'></a>
### both `constants`

##### Summary

Triggers on rising and falling edges.

<a name='F-busy'></a>
### busy `constants`

##### Summary

Represents the busy pin.

##### Remarks

This pin is true on low logic.

This pin cannot be set in user mode.

<a name='F-centaur'></a>
### centaur `constants`

##### Summary

Identifies a Centaur CPU.

<a name='F-command_error'></a>
### command_error `constants`

##### Summary

This bit is set if a command was syntactically incorrect or
undefined.

<a name='F-count'></a>
### count `constants`

##### Summary

Capture the specified number of samples.

<a name='F-cpu'></a>
### cpu `constants`

##### Summary

`ADL_PMLOG_CPU_POWER`.

<a name='F-current'></a>
### current `constants`

##### Summary

Request sampling the current sensor only.

<a name='F-cyrix'></a>
### cyrix `constants`

##### Summary

Identifies a Cyrix CPU.

<a name='F-data'></a>
### data `constants`

##### Summary

Represents all data pins.

<a name='F-data0'></a>
### data0 `constants`

##### Summary

The first data pin.

<a name='F-data1'></a>
### data1 `constants`

##### Summary

The second data pin.

<a name='F-data2'></a>
### data2 `constants`

##### Summary

The third data pin.

<a name='F-data3'></a>
### data3 `constants`

##### Summary

The fourth data pin.

<a name='F-data4'></a>
### data4 `constants`

##### Summary

The fifth data pin.

<a name='F-data5'></a>
### data5 `constants`

##### Summary

The sixth data pin.

<a name='F-data6'></a>
### data6 `constants`

##### Summary

The seventh data pin.

<a name='F-data7'></a>
### data7 `constants`

##### Summary

The eighth data pin.

<a name='F-device_dependent_error'></a>
### device_dependent_error `constants`

##### Summary

This bit is set if a device-dependent error occurred.

<a name='F-direct_current'></a>
### direct_current `constants`

##### Summary

Direct current coupling.

<a name='F-direct_current_limit'></a>
### direct_current_limit `constants`

##### Summary

DC coupling passes the input signal unchanged.

<a name='F-dram'></a>
### dram `constants`

##### Summary

The DRAM package.

<a name='F-duration'></a>
### duration `constants`

##### Summary

Capture for the specified duration after start.

<a name='F-elbrus'></a>
### elbrus `constants`

##### Summary

Identifies an MCST Elbrus CPU.

<a name='F-end'></a>
### end `constants`

##### Summary

End of file.

<a name='F-energy'></a>
### energy `constants`

##### Summary

Energy in Joules or derived from it.

<a name='F-error'></a>
### error `constants`

##### Summary

The error pin.

##### Remarks

This pin cannot be set in user mode.

<a name='F-error_queue_not_empty'></a>
### error_queue_not_empty `constants`

##### Summary

This bit is set if at least one entry is in the error queue.

<a name='F-execution_error'></a>
### execution_error `constants`

##### Summary

This bit is set if a command was syntactically correct, but cannot
be processed for other reasons.

<a name='F-explicitly'></a>
### explicitly `constants`

##### Summary

Use the explicitly set range.

##### Remarks

A valid value for the range must be provided in this case. Consult
the documentation of the instrument to find out what valid values
for the quantity in question are.

<a name='F-falling'></a>
### falling `constants`

##### Summary

Triggers on the falling edge only.

<a name='F-first'></a>
### first `constants`

##### Summary

Use the first sample point in the waveform.

<a name='F-full'></a>
### full `constants`

##### Summary

Use the full bandwidth.

<a name='F-graphics'></a>
### graphics `constants`

##### Summary

`ADL_PMLOG_GFX_POWER`.

<a name='F-ground'></a>
### ground `constants`

##### Summary

Connection to a virtual ground.

<a name='F-ground0'></a>
### ground0 `constants`

##### Summary

The first ground pin.

##### Remarks

This pin cannot be set.

<a name='F-ground1'></a>
### ground1 `constants`

##### Summary

The second ground pin.

##### Remarks

This pin cannot be set.

<a name='F-ground2'></a>
### ground2 `constants`

##### Summary

The third ground pin.

##### Remarks

This pin cannot be set.

<a name='F-ground3'></a>
### ground3 `constants`

##### Summary

The fourth ground pin.

##### Remarks

This pin cannot be set.

<a name='F-ground4'></a>
### ground4 `constants`

##### Summary

The fifth ground pin.

##### Remarks

This pin cannot be set.

<a name='F-ground5'></a>
### ground5 `constants`

##### Summary

The sixth ground pin.

##### Remarks

This pin cannot be set.

<a name='F-ground6'></a>
### ground6 `constants`

##### Summary

The seventh ground pin.

##### Remarks

This pin cannot be set.

<a name='F-ground7'></a>
### ground7 `constants`

##### Summary

The eighth ground pin.

##### Remarks

This pin cannot be set.

<a name='F-high'></a>
### high `constants`

##### Summary

Large range.

<a name='F-high_resolution'></a>
### high_resolution `constants`

##### Summary

The average of n sample points is recorded as waveform point.

<a name='F-hundred_nanoseconds'></a>
### hundred_nanoseconds `constants`

##### Summary

Timestamp is specified in units of hundred nanoseconds (the native
quantity of many Windows APIs).

<a name='F-hygon'></a>
### hygon `constants`

##### Summary

Identifies a Hygon CPU.

<a name='F-hyperv'></a>
### hyperv `constants`

##### Summary

Identifies the HyperV hypervisor.

<a name='F-intel'></a>
### intel `constants`

##### Summary

Identifies an Intel CPU.

<a name='F-interrupt'></a>
### interrupt `constants`

##### Summary

Immediately interrupt the current acquisition.

<a name='F-inverted'></a>
### inverted `constants`

##### Summary

Reflect the voltage values of all signal components against the
ground level.

##### Remarks

Inversion affects only the display of the signal, but not the
trigger.

<a name='F-kvm'></a>
### kvm `constants`

##### Summary

Identifies the KVM hypervisor.

<a name='F-last'></a>
### last `constants`

##### Summary

Use the last sample point in the waveform.

<a name='F-left'></a>
### left `constants`

##### Summary

The scaling origin is located on the left side of the diagram.

<a name='F-limit_to_20_mhz'></a>
### limit_to_20_mhz `constants`

##### Summary

Limit to 20 Mhz in order to reduce high-frequency noise.

<a name='F-line_feed'></a>
### line_feed `constants`

##### Summary

The pin indicating a line feed.

<a name='F-low'></a>
### low `constants`

##### Summary

Small range.

<a name='F-low_frequency_reject'></a>
### low_frequency_reject `constants`

##### Summary

High-frequency coupling, which enables a 15 kHz high-pass filter
to remove lower frequencies from the trigger signal.

<a name='F-mask'></a>
### mask `constants`

##### Summary

Outputs a pulse when a mask is violated.

<a name='F-master_status'></a>
### master_status `constants`

##### Summary

This bit is set if the instrument has issues a service request.

<a name='F-maximum'></a>
### maximum `constants`

##### Summary

All points a maximum resolution as they are available in memory.

<a name='F-maximum_visible'></a>
### maximum_visible `constants`

##### Summary

Points at maximum resolution available in memory, but only for the
visible range.

<a name='F-mean'></a>
### mean `constants`

##### Summary

Compute the arithmetic mean.

<a name='F-medium'></a>
### medium `constants`

##### Summary

Medium range.

<a name='F-message_available'></a>
### message_available `constants`

##### Summary

This bit is set if a message is available in the output buffer.

### microseconds `constants`

Timestamp is specified in microsecond (Millionth of a second).

### microseconds_588 `constants`

##### Summary

A conversion time of 588 µs.

##### Summary

layer.

### milliseconds_8_244 `constants`

##### Summary

A conversion time of 8.244 ms.

<a name='F-minimum'></a>
### minimum `constants`

##### Summary

Use the minimum possible range.

<a name='F-nanoseconds'></a>
### nanoseconds `constants`

##### Summary

Timestamp is specified in nanoseconds (Billionth of a second).

<a name='F-national_semiconductor'></a>
### national_semiconductor `constants`

Identifies a National Semiconductor CPU.

<a name='F-nexgen'></a>

<a name='F-none'></a>

<a name='F-normal'></a>
### normal `constants`

The data are unmodified

<a name='F-off'></a>
### off `constants`

##### Summary

The auxilliary output is disabled.

<a name='F-operation_complete'></a>
### operation_complete `constants`

 recorded as waveform points.

### start(sampling_period) `method`

##### Summary

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| sampling_period | [System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The desired sampling period in

##### Remarks

This method is for expert use only. It puts the sensor into
sampling state, but does not deliver the data to any callback.
Instead, callers are expected to retrieve data using the
synchronous [sample](#M-visus-power_overwhelming-adl_sensor-sample-=FUNC-System-Void-visus-power_overwhelming-measurement!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst*!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsImplicitlyDereferenced,System-Void*-,System-UInt64!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst,System-Void*- 'visus.power_overwhelming.adl_sensor.sample(=FUNC:System.Void(visus.power_overwhelming.measurement!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsImplicitlyDereferenced,System.Void*),System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst,System.Void*)') method in a separate thread.
Note that putting the sensor in sampling state this way will prevent
the asynchronous [sample](#M-visus-power_overwhelming-adl_sensor-sample-=FUNC-System-Void-visus-power_overwhelming-measurement!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst*!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsImplicitlyDereferenced,System-Void*-,System-UInt64!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst,System-Void*- 'visus.power_overwhelming.adl_sensor.sample(=FUNC:System.Void(visus.power_overwhelming.measurement!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsImplicitlyDereferenced,System.Void*),System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst,System.Void*)') method from working. You
should therefore either use either of the methods and never mix
them.

sampling will be stopped as well.

It is safe to call this method on a sensor that is not
sampling asynchronously or that has been disposed by a move
operation.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-detail-adl_sensor_impl-sample-visus-power_overwhelming-timestamp_resolution!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst-'></a>
### sample(resolution) `method`

##### Summary

Obtain a single sample from the sensor.

##### Returns

The current measurement from the sensor.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| resolution | [visus.power_overwhelming.timestamp_resolution!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-timestamp_resolution!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst 'visus.power_overwhelming.timestamp_resolution!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The resolution of the timestamp being
returned. |

##### Remarks

The sensor must be running in order to produce meaningful
results. The implementation does not verify that, though, for
performance reasons. Callers must make sure that this invariant
is met.

The method checks how the data in [start_output](#F-visus-power_overwhelming-detail-adl_sensor_impl-start_output 'visus.power_overwhelming.detail.adl_sensor_impl.start_output')
are best converted into an instance of [measurement](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-measurement 'visus.power_overwhelming.measurement')
(based on the sensor readings available) and creates the instance
for the [sensor_name](#F-visus-power_overwhelming-detail-adl_sensor_impl-sensor_name 'visus.power_overwhelming.detail.adl_sensor_impl.sensor_name').

Valid combinations of input data are: power measurements only,
measurements of voltage and current and measurement of all of the
sensors before. Any other combination will cause the method to
fail.

HAZARD: It is totally unclear to me how AMD achieves thread
safety with that. The code is taken from their sample
https://github.com/GPUOpen-LibrariesAndSDKs/display-library/blob/79cdb8e22b8650c861b390d5a9895032492ce8c5/Sample/PMLog/PMLog.cpp
which is completely unprotected against races IMHO.

visus.power_overwhelming

##### Summary

##### Remarks

[async_sampling](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-async_sampling 'visus.power_overwhelming.async_sampling') is not thread-safe. It is intended

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-async_sampling-stores_and_passes_context-System-Void*,=FUNC-System-Void-System-Void*--'></a>
### stores_and_passes_context(context,context_deleter) `method`

##### Summary

Stores `context` as the context of the callback
and changes ownership of the context to the object, which will use
`context_deleter` to free it.

##### Returns

`*this`.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| context | [System.Void*](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.Void* 'System.Void*') | The context to be passed to the callback. The
object takes ownership of this object provided that
`context_deleter` is not `nullptr`. |

##### Remarks

This method can be used to create "fire-and-forget"
configurations that manage context objects on the heap by
themselves. An example for using it would be:

```
config.stores_and_passes_context(::malloc(42), ::free);
```

Typically, you would not just allocate typeless memory on the heap
here, but construct and destruct objects. To facilitate this use
case, there are templated overloads that accept context objects and
create deleters that destruct and free those objects on your behalf.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-blob-reserve-System-UInt64!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst-'></a>
### reserve(size) `method`

##### Summary

Make sure that the blob can hold at least `size`
bytes.

##### Returns

`true` if the blob was reallocated, `false` if
the previous capacity was sufficient.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| size | [System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The required minimum size of the blob, in bytes. |

##### Exceptions

| Name | Description |
| ---- | ----------- |
| [std.bad_alloc](#T-std-bad_alloc 'std.bad_alloc') | If the required memory could not
be allocated. |

##### Remarks

Reserving data may invalidate existing data if the requested
minimum size is larger than the current size. Existing data will
not be copied to the new memory block in this case. The method will
incicate this by returning `true`. If the method returns
`false`, the existing allocation and its content remain
untouched.

You can use [grow](#M-visus-power_overwhelming-blob-grow-System-UInt64!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst- 'visus.power_overwhelming.blob.grow(System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst)') if existing content of
the blob needs to be preserved while increasing its capacity.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-blob-resize-System-UInt64!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst-'></a>
### resize(size) `method`

##### Summary

`size` in bytes.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| size | [System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The requested size in bytes. |

##### Exceptions

| Name | Description |
| ---- | ----------- |
| [std.bad_alloc](#T-std-bad_alloc 'std.bad_alloc') | If the required memory could not
be allocated. |

##### Remarks

If the buffer does not already have the requested size, any
existing data will be lost.

You can achieve the same effect by calling
[truncate](#M-visus-power_overwhelming-blob-truncate-System-UInt64!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst- 'visus.power_overwhelming.blob.truncate(System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst)'), but preserve any exisiting content
during the operation.

<a name='T-visus-power_overwhelming-cpu_info'></a>
## cpu_info `type`

##### Namespace

visus.power_overwhelming

##### Summary

Represents the data that are received from the x86 CPUID instruction.

##### Remarks

The values retrieved from the registers depend on the index
queried from the CPU. Out implementation retrieves these in order, i.e.
the first element is at index 0 and holds the vendor string, the one at
index 1 holds the model information and so on.

<a name='F-visus-power_overwhelming-cpu_info-values'></a>
### values `constants`

##### Summary

A contiguous view on the registers.

<a name='T-visus-power_overwhelming-cpu_vendor'></a>
## cpu_vendor `type`

##### Namespace

visus.power_overwhelming

##### Summary

Specifies different vendors of CPUs.

##### Remarks

Some sensors, most notably the [msr_sensor](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-msr_sensor 'visus.power_overwhelming.msr_sensor') are
dependent on vendor-specific implementations. This enumeration
identifies the supported CPU vendors.

Callers should not make any assumption about the numeric values
of the enumeration except for [unknown](#F-unknown 'unknown') being
zero.

<a name='T-visus-power_overwhelming-detail-emi_device'></a>
## emi_device `type`

##### Namespace

visus.power_overwhelming.detail

##### Summary

Private wrapper around the device handle for an EMI-capable piece of
hardware.

##### Remarks

There are multiple reasons for this class existing. First, we need
to manage the file handle (RAII) and ideally cache the metadata for
multiple requests. Second, as EMIv2 has multiple channels per device,
multiple sensors may share one device. Therefore, we want to be able to
share a device between multiple sensor implementations such that we can
query all channels at once in an asynchronous sampling scenario.

### version() `method`

##### Summary

Answer the version of the Energy Meter Interface used by the sensor.

##### Returns



##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |

##### Remarks

The sensor behaves differently depending on the EMI version
provided by the operating system: first, when using the raw
version of the sampling method, the caller needs to know which
structure to pass as input parameter. Second, when using EMI version
2, the sensor reads multiple channels at once.

| Name | Type | Description |

| value | [System.Int32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.Int32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.Int32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The current range in Volts. This parameter

| Name | Description |
| ---- | ----------- |
| [std.runtime_error](#T-std-runtime_error 'std.runtime_error') | If the method is called on an
object that has been disposed by moving it. |
| [visa_exception](#!-visa_exception 'visa_exception') | If the VISA command was not
processed successfully. |

##### Remarks

The instrument can be instructed to select a reasonable range
by specifying [automatically](#F-automatically 'automatically').
However, this will prevent a correct integration of measurements if
the range changes during the measurement period. Therefore, it is
reasonable to specify a safe range explictly in such an application
case.

<a name='T-visus-power_overwhelming-detail-library_base'></a>
## library_base `type`

##### Namespace

visus.power_overwhelming.detail

##### Summary

Base class for managing libraries that are lazily loaded.

##### Remarks

Rationale: If we statically link against vendor-specific management
libraries, applications will only work if all of these libraries are
available on the system, ie. if the system has NVIDIA and AMD GPUs. This
is highly unlikely. Explicitly loading the libraries on demand solves
this issue.

### resize(series,size) `method`

##### Summary

Resizes the data series to the specified number of elements, keeping
at most `series` of the existing values.

##### Returns

A pointer to the new begin of the values in
`series`.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| series | [visus.power_overwhelming.measurement_data_series*!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsImplicitlyDereferenced](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-measurement_data_series*!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsImplicitlyDereferenced 'visus.power_overwhelming.measurement_data_series*!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsImplicitlyDereferenced') | The series to be resized. |
| size | [System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The new size of the data series. |

##### Exceptions

| Name | Description |
| ---- | ----------- |
| [std.bad_alloc](#T-std-bad_alloc 'std.bad_alloc') | If the allocation of heap memory
for the data failed. |

##### Remarks

Typically, this method is only used by sensors generating data
series who need to grow the buffer to store new samples.

If the data series is growing, the values past the original
size of the series are initialised as invalid. Callers should make
sure to truncate the data series to the range of valid samples
before handing it to any client code.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-msr_sensor-force_create-System-UInt32!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst,visus-power_overwhelming-rapl_domain!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst,System-Int64!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst,System-Int64!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst,System-UInt64!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst,System-UInt32!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst-'></a>
### force_create(core,domain,data_location) `method`

##### Summary

Creates a new sensor for the specified core and RAPL domain,
forcing the specified [](#!-offset 'offset') for the location of the
energy sample in the MSR device file.

##### Returns

A new instance of the MSR sensor for the specified
configuration.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| core | [System.UInt32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.UInt32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.UInt32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The index of the CPU core for which the MSR
sensor should be opened. |
| domain | [visus.power_overwhelming.rapl_domain!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-rapl_domain!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst 'visus.power_overwhelming.rapl_domain!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The RAPL domain that is being sampled by the
sensor. This information is only used for creating the sensor name,
but has no effect on the actual data that are being read by the
sensor. |
| data_location | [System.Int64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.Int64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.Int64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The offset into the MSR device file
where the samlpes are read from. |

##### Exceptions

| Name | Description |
| ---- | ----------- |
| [std.system_error](#T-std-system_error 'std.system_error') | If the MSR device file could not
be opened. |

##### Remarks

This factory method exists due to the fact that the whole RAPL
stuff is poorly documented and the implementation is copied from
all over the internet. Furthermore, there is no centralised
implementation for that stuff in Linux we can rely on to be up to
date. Therefore, this method provides the opportunity for callers
who know that a specific CPU supports a specific RAPL domain at a
specific offset in the MSR device file to force the creation of the
sensor, bypassing all built-in sanity checks based on the
aforementioned sketchy information.

As NVML uses an internal reference counter, multiple scopes can be used
by an application. NVML will not be unloaded unless the last scope was
destroyed.

<a name='T-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_acquisition'></a>
## rtx_acquisition `type`

##### Namespace

visus.power_overwhelming

##### Summary

Configures the acquisition mode of the oscilloscope.

##### Remarks

Not all properties might be relevant for all modes.

For programmatic measurements, callers should typically configure
a single acquisition (possibly with multiple segments) as free running
acquisitions cannot be safely synchronised with the application logic.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_acquisition-segmented-System-Boolean!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst-'></a>
### segmented(segmented) `method`

##### Summary

Enables or disables fast segmentation.

##### Returns

`*this`.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| segmented | [System.Boolean!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.Boolean!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.Boolean!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | `true` to enable fast segmentation,
`false` to disable it. |

##### Remarks

If fast segmentation is enabled, the acquisitions are
performed as fast as possible without processing and displaying the
waveforms. Once the acquisition has been stopped, the data is
processed and the latest waveform is displayed. Older waveforms are
 stored in segments.

This setting is primarily for single acqusition mode.

### zero_offset() `method`

##### Summary

Sets the zero offset.

##### Returns

`*this`.

##### Parameters

This method has no parameters.

##### Remarks

Differences in the device under test (DUT) and oscilloscope
ground levels may cause larger zero errors affecting the waveform.
If the DUT is ground-referenced, the zero offset corrects the zero
error andsets the probe to the zero level.

You can assess the zero error by measuring the mean value of
a signal that should return zero.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-parallel_port_trigger-morse-System-Char!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst*,System-UInt32!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst,visus-power_overwhelming-parallel_port_pin!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst,visus-power_overwhelming-parallel_port_pin!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst-'></a>
### morse(code,base_time,on,off) `method`

##### Summary

Write the given Morse code to the parallel port.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| code | [System.Char!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.Char!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst* 'System.Char!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*') | The Morse code to write. |
| base_time | [System.UInt32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.UInt32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.UInt32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The base time of the code (a dit) in
milliseconds. This parameter defaults to 200 ms. |
| on | [visus.power_overwhelming.parallel_port_pin!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-parallel_port_pin!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst 'visus.power_overwhelming.parallel_port_pin!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The pins to turn on, which defaults to all. |
| off | [visus.power_overwhelming.parallel_port_pin!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-parallel_port_pin!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst 'visus.power_overwhelming.parallel_port_pin!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The pins to turn off, which defaults to all data
pins. |

##### Exceptions

| Name | Description |
| ---- | ----------- |
| [std::system_error](#!-std--system_error 'std::system_error') | If the data could not be written
to the port. |

##### Remarks

The morse code is made of dots for short pulses and hyphens
for long ones. Characters are separated by spaces (that represents a
pause of three dits) and words are separated by a slash (that
represents a puase of seven dits). For instance, to write
"Power Overwhelming", you would need to morse
`.--. --- .-- . .-. / --- ...- . .-. .-- .... . .-.. -- .. -. --.
`.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-get_cpu_vendor'></a>
### get_cpu_vendor() `method`

##### Summary

Determines the vendor of the CPUs on the system.

##### Returns

An enumeration value identifying the CPU vendor or
[unknown](#F-unknown 'unknown') if the CPU vendor could not be
determined.

##### Parameters

This method has no parameters.

##### Remarks

This function works using the CPUID intrinsics. For the unlikely case
that the code is running on a machine with different kinds of CPUs, the
caller should set the thread affinity to the desired CPU in order to
make sure that the CPUID registers of the expected processors are read.
The [set_thread_affinity](#M-visus-power_overwhelming-set_thread_affinity-System-UInt32!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst- 'visus.power_overwhelming.set_thread_affinity(System.UInt32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst)') function can be used for this
purpose.

<a name='T-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_instrument'></a>
## rtx_instrument `type`

##### Namespace

visus.power_overwhelming

##### Summary

Specialisation for a Rohde & Schwarz RTA/RTB oscilloscope.

##### Remarks

This specialisation only provides additional APIs for commonly
used commands on the oscilloscopes. The rationale for exposing this
in a separate public class rather than putting it in the sensor is
twofold: First, there might be cases for controlling the oscilloscopes
that are not related to Power Overwhelming sensors. By using this class,
you can do that without reimplementing the logic for all of the methods
in this class. Second, there are things that need to be configured
only once, even if there are two sensors configured on a four-port
oscilloscope. By iterating over all [](#!-rtx_instruments 'rtx_instruments'),
these settings can be made easily without tracking the topology of
the oscilloscope sensors manually.

<a name='T-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_instrument_configuration'></a>
## rtx_instrument_configuration `type`

##### Namespace

visus.power_overwhelming

##### Summary

This class stores the shared part of the configuration of an
[](#!-rtx_sensor 'rtx_sensor'), which cannot be configured individually if
multiple sensors are created on the same [rtx_instrument](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_instrument 'visus.power_overwhelming.rtx_instrument').

##### Remarks

When using an oscilloscope with four channels or more, it is
possible to create an [](#!-rtx_sensor 'rtx_sensor') for each pair of
channels (one for voltage and one for current), thus having more than
one sensor operating on the same [rtx_instrument](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_instrument 'visus.power_overwhelming.rtx_instrument'). In this
situation, not all of the parameters of the instrument can be configured
individually. For instance, the length of the waveform being recorded
on a trigger signal is the same for all channels. This configuration
object groups all of these settings that will be shared between sensors
on the same instrument.

Settings grouped in this class need to be set only once for the
set of sensors created from the same instruments. Likewise, it is
strongly recommended to apply the same settings to all instruments when
working with multiple oscilloscopes in order to produce consistent
results.

This class does not at all interact with the actual instrument
until the configuration is applied. Therefore, it is possible to create
configurations that are invalid without noticing it until the
configuration is realised.

Although it is possible to configure settings that are only
relevant on a per-sensor basis, most notably the channels, using this
class, you should never do this when using it in conjunction with
[](#!-rtx_sensor 'rtx_sensor') as this might apply an invalid configuration
for this use case. Make sure to call [ignore_all_channels](#M-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_instrument_configuration-ignore_all_channels 'visus.power_overwhelming.rtx_instrument_configuration.ignore_all_channels')
when working with a configuration object that you have not built
yourself.

This class effectively implements the builder pattern for
RTA/RTB oscilloscope instances.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_instrument_configuration-#ctor-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_quantity!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst,System-UInt32!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst,System-UInt32-'></a>
### #ctor(time_range,samples,timeout) `constructor`

##### Summary

Initialises a new instance.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| time_range | [visus.power_overwhelming.rtx_quantity!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_quantity!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst 'visus.power_overwhelming.rtx_quantity!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The time range the oscilloscope should
acquire after it has been triggers. |
| samples | [System.UInt32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.UInt32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.UInt32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The number of samples to be acquired during
`time_range`. If this is zero, which is the
default, the instrument will be configured to determine the best
number of samples on its own. |
| timeout | [System.UInt32](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.UInt32 'System.UInt32') | The timeout of the instrument (for connections
and for I/O operations including `*OPC?` queries. If this value
is zero, which is the default, the timeout will not be modified. Be
aware that you must be able to wait for acqusitions to complete, so
the timeout should be larger than the time range you intend to
acquire. |

##### Remarks

The default configuration uses the defaults of the
[](#!-rtx_single_acquisition 'rtx_single_acquisition') and
[rtx_edge_trigger](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_edge_trigger 'visus.power_overwhelming.rtx_edge_trigger') with the following changes:
On the acquisition, fast-segmentation is enabled and the number of
points is computed automatically. The rationally for that is that we
want the instrument to be as fast as possible in production mode.
Furthermore, computing the number of samples automatically is most
suitable for this construction, which is designed to require the
least user input possible. The edge trigger is configured in
[automatic](#F-automatic 'automatic') automatic, which
ensures that the instrument forces a trigger if none occurs on the
device. This might not be desirable if working with external
triggers on the instrument, but it is the least error-prone way to
configure the instrument. Therefore, it is again the most reasonable
thing for this simplified constructor. If you have additional
requirements, you must configure new instances using fully
customised configuration objects.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_instrument_configuration-min_time_base-System-Single!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst-'></a>
### min_time_base(min_time_base) `method`

##### Summary

Sets the minimum time base for which roll mode is enabled
automatically if the length of a division is undercut.

##### Returns

`*this`.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| min_time_base | [System.Single!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.Single!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.Single!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The minimum time base in seconds. |

##### Remarks

The instrument will enable roll mode automatically (which is
typically not desirable for automated measurement application cases)
if the length of a division undercuts the value configured here. The
default value for RTA/RTB instruments is half a second for this
value.

There are a few special cases in this implementation: If you
set a value of zero or a negative one, the method will disable
`TIM:ROLL:AUT`. If you set exactly zero, the maximum possible
value for `TIM:ROLL:MTIM` will be set, effectively preventing
for automatic roll to ever happen. If the value is negative, its
absolute will be set as the effective value.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_sensor-acquire-visus-power_overwhelming-timestamp_resolution!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst-'></a>
### acquire(rhs,resolution) `method`

##### Summary

Move `rhs` into a new instance.

##### Returns

The data series for the waveforms acquired from the
instrument.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| rhs | [visus.power_overwhelming.timestamp_resolution!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-timestamp_resolution!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst 'visus.power_overwhelming.timestamp_resolution!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The object to be moved. |

##### Remarks

This method assumes that the instrument and its channels have
been properly configured and not been changed since. Most
importantly, it is assume that the instrument is in single
acquisition mode.

The method will run a single acquisition on the instrument and
afterwards download the full-resolution data of the channels
configured for voltage and current for this sensor. Other sensors
using the same instrument might acquire data as well, but these will
not be processed.

This method will block until the acquisition completed.
Callers must make sure that, if a trigger has been configured and
the instrument is triggering in normal mode, the trigger actually
occurs within the timeout period of the instrument. If the
acquisition times out because of the lack of a trigger, the method
will fail.

This method will download two waveforms from the instrument at
their native resolution. This might take a significant amount of
time, during which the calling thread will be blocked, depending on
the number of sample points the underlying instrument is configured
to obtain for a single acquisition.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-rtx_sensor-instrument'></a>
### instrument() `method`

##### Summary

Answer the instrument that is being used by the sensor.

##### Returns

The instrument used by the sensor. The sensor remains the
owner of the memory returned. Callers must not release or move the
instrument returned.

##### Parameters

This method has no parameters.

##### Remarks

The instrument may be used by more than one sensor. Make sure
not to make any changes to the configuration of the instrument that
might influence the sensors created on the instrument. Additionally,
you should not trigger manual acquisitions on an instrument that is
used by one or more sensors, but only acquire data via the sensor.

<a name='T-visus-power_overwhelming-detail-sampler_source'></a>
## sampler_source `type`

##### Namespace

visus.power_overwhelming.detail

##### Summary

This class defines the interface for sources that can be sampled by the
generic [](#!-sampler_thread 'sampler_thread').

##### Remarks

This interface is typically implemented by the implementation
classes of a sensor, but in some cases, it might be easier if the sensor
implements it by itself. In general, there is no use for end users of
the Power Overwhelming library in using this interface.

Sensors that are inherently synchronous can use the template
[](#!-basic_sampler_source 'basic_sampler_source') to make their implementation object
a source of asynchronous samples without any additional implementation
effort.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-detail-sampler_source-deliver'></a>
### deliver() `method`

##### Summary

Synchronously delivers a sample to the registered callback or
callbacks.

##### Returns

`true` if a sample was delivered and the source can and
should be sampled again in the future, `false` otherwise.

##### Parameters

This method has no parameters.

##### Remarks

If this method returns `false`, the sampler must
unregister the source immediately and not use it again for any
purpose. Callers shall treat the pointer to a source returning
`false` as dangling references.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-detail-sampler_source-interval'></a>
### interval() `method`

##### Summary

Answers the requested sampling interval of the source.

##### Returns

##### Parameters

This method has no parameters.

<a name='M-visus-power_overwhelming-sensor-sample_data-visus-power_overwhelming-timestamp_resolution!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst-'></a>
### sample_data(resolution) `method`

##### Summary

Sample the sensor using a timestamp with the specified resolution,
but do not attach the sensor that produces the data to the sample.

##### Returns

A single measurement made by the sensor.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| resolution | [visus.power_overwhelming.timestamp_resolution!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-timestamp_resolution!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst 'visus.power_overwhelming.timestamp_resolution!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The resolution of the timestamp to be
created. This value basically determines the unit in which the
timestamp in the return value is measured. This parameter defaults
to [milliseconds](#F-milliseconds 'milliseconds'). |

##### Exceptions

| Name | Description |
| ---- | ----------- |
| [std.runtime_error](#T-std-runtime_error 'std.runtime_error') | If a sensor that has been moved
(and therefore disposed) is sampled. |
| [adl_exception](#!-adl_exception 'adl_exception') | If an ADL sensor could not be
sampled. |
| [nvml_exception](#!-nvml_exception 'nvml_exception') | If an NVML sensor could not be
sampled. |
| [tinkerforge_exception](#!-tinkerforge_exception 'tinkerforge_exception') | If a Tinkerforge sensor
could not be sampled. |
| [visa_exception](#!-visa_exception 'visa_exception') | If a sensor based on a VISA
instrument could not be sampled. |
| [std.system_error](#T-std-system_error 'std.system_error') | If a sensor could not be sampled
due to a system call failing. |

##### Remarks

This new method is an alternative to
[sample](#M-visus-power_overwhelming-sensor-sample-visus-power_overwhelming-timestamp_resolution!System-Runtime-CompilerServices-IsConst- 'visus.power_overwhelming.sensor.sample(visus.power_overwhelming.timestamp_resolution!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst)') that does not incur the cost for
copying the name of the sensor producing the data to the sample. It
is suitable for applications that keep track of the sensors and the
samples on their own and that cause the least possible overhead on
the machine the code is running on. This is specifically interesting
for applications using sensors that can only be sampled on the
machine under observation, like GPU power sensors and the RAPL
registers.

Please be aware that you might not be able to obtain all
information about the sensor that the data originate from when
using this method. This is the case if the underlying API can
produce samples from different sources. Such sensors must be
configured to make sure that they only return the data expected
when using this method for sampling.

Rationale: The naming of this method (and of
[measurement_data](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-measurement_data 'visus.power_overwhelming.measurement_data')) is a bit weird, which is due to the
fact that samples without the originating sensor embedded have been
added later to the library. The previous type and method names have
not been changed at this point in order to not break existing code
relying on the library.

<a name='T-visus-power_overwhelming-detail-tinkerforge_scope'></a>
## tinkerforge_scope `type`

##### Namespace

visus.power_overwhelming.detail

##### Summary

RAII container for a Tinkerforge brick connection.

##### Remarks

Tinkerforge scopes can be shared on a per-connection basis. The
scope keeps a reference count for each connection and terminates it once
the last instance was destructed.

Callers must make sure to adhere the thread-safety requirements
of the Tingerforge [](#D-IPConnection 'IPConnection') they can obtain from a
scope. The creation of new scopes and their destruction is, however,
thread-safe.

### get_definitions(dst,cnt,timeout,host,port) `method`

##### Summary

Retrieve sensor definitions for all bricklets attacted to the
specified host.

##### Returns

The number of current/voltage bricklets available,
regardless of how many have been copied.

##### Parameters

| Name | Type | Description |
| ---- | ---- | ----------- |
| dst | [visus.power_overwhelming.tinkerforge_sensor_definition*](#T-visus-power_overwhelming-tinkerforge_sensor_definition* 'visus.power_overwhelming.tinkerforge_sensor_definition*') | Receives the sensor definitions. If
`nullptr`, the sensors will only be counted. |
| cnt | [System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | Size of
`dst` in elements. It is safe to pass
any number if `dst` is `nullptr`.
In this case, the number is interpreted as the expected number of
bricklets to wait for. |
| timeout | [System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.UInt64!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The number of milliseconds to wait for the
bricklets to connect if none are cached. This value defaults to
1000. |
| host | [System.SByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsSignUnspecifiedByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.SByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsSignUnspecifiedByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst* 'System.SByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsSignUnspecifiedByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*') | The host on which the Brick daemon is running.
This parameter defaults to "localhost". |
| port | [System.UInt16!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst](http://msdn.microsoft.com/query/dev14.query?appId=Dev14IDEF1&l=EN-US&k=k:System.UInt16!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst 'System.UInt16!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst') | The port on which the Brick daemon is listening.
This parameter defaults to 4223. |

##### Remarks

Tinkerforge bricklets are discovered asynchronously via
a network protocol. Therefore, it might take some time to find
all of them and it is impossible to know for sure whether the
currently know set of bricklets is the actual ones. However,
the library keeps a list of already discovered bricklets, which
is updated in background and returned if it is non-empty. Otherwise,
ie in case of an empty list, the method waits for at most
`timeout` milliseconds for the bricklets to
appear.

Due to the asynchronous detection of bricklets and the fact
that bricklets are fully hot-plug capable and therefore can also
be removed at any time, the method might return spurious numbers
of bricklets which need to be handled by the caller. It is
absolutely mandatory to check the return value! If the return
value is larger than `cnt_definitions`, the caller
should increase the buffer size and call the method again. If the
returned number of brickles is smaller than
`cnt_definitions`, the remaining elements in
the output array are invalid and must not be used. Spurious return
values can even occur when using the pattern of calling the method
with `nullptr` for `dst` to
count the required space, allocating this space and then calling
it again. This is due to the cached bricklets only being locked
when inside the method, not between calls.

Callers should try to avoid specifying larger numbers
for `cnt_definitions` than the actually available
number of current/voltage bricklets, because the method assumes
that this is the epected number and waits until the timeout if
less bricklets than this number are actually connected. A reasonable
pattern is determining the number of current/voltage bricklets by
calling the method without an output buffer, the expected number
as and a fairly large timeout
to give the method time to actually discover all of the expected
bricklets. Callers should then allocate the required output buffer
and call the method again with a small timeout.

##### Remarks

This method does nothing if the library was compiled without

Within the methods of the instrument, there are checks of the
system state of the instrument after important changes. If you
enable these system checks, the code will fail early in case you
make any change that puts the system into an invalid state. By
default, the checks are disabled, because they cause significant
overhead. It is suggested to enable this only for debugging purposes
during development.

This method will issue an `*OPC?` query immediately after
the reset request in order to make sure that the calling code is
blocked until the instrument finished resetting. If the I/O buffers
are flushed and/or the status bits are cleared, these operations
are also guaranteed to have completed before the method returns.
